div1.head: Jim to Mlle Marcelle Guerin, Monday October 11th [1915]
div1.p: Ca y est. So I shall see you in about a month and a half. I feel it my duty to remain here until Salisbury’s return, which will be within that time. On my way to the school I will be in Paris a couple of days at least, and if it is not too cold you simply must take a day off and lead me around Versailles once more. Tell the leaves the must not fall until after I leave.

I saw a wonderful sight yesterday. Boche aeroplanes had been bothering us all day. One was behind us and an anti-air-craft gun was firing at it. The puffs of shrapnel were so close and plentiful they blended into a long cloud bank. Suddenly a fast French chasseur plane shot out of the smoke and at a terrific speed made for the enemy plane. He swerved alongside and slightly under. There was the whirr of a mitrailleuse and the German plane lurched forward. It pointed nose down
and fell like a great wounded bird. A trail of blue smoke streaked in its wake. It was a jolting, flopping fall, but very fast, and as it turned this way and that in its lifeless descent the sun glittered on the under side of the flames. Down it came. It was harrowing to watch it knowing that tho [sic] the pilote [sic] had been killed the observer was probably living. It crashed into a forest. I don’t know why I said it but I turned to Haviland and remarked “Plunk. They're dead.” The soldiers set up a wild yell of delight crying “Bravo!” and clapping their hands. The Frenchman, in the same graceful machine you see over the ambulance swooped downward in a giant circle; a triumphal circuit it seemed, and went over the place where the German had fallen. One of our men was in the woods. The machine fell 400 meters from him. He said it was terrible. There was nothing left of the machine. The bodies of the two German captains in the aero were mangled beyond recognition. The engine had
fallen on the pilote [sic] and cut him in two. His legs were a bit of a distance off. His liver was stuck on the motor.

This morning our man guided my aviator friend and the one that had done the trick to the scene. The victor looked at the mangled bodies and took off his hat. He seemed sad. After that he came to lunch with us. He’s the most modest, retiring little fellow you ever met. I had a piece of wing cloth from the machine and he signed it for me. I’m glad I’m to be pilote [sic] and not observer for then one is killed at the start and doesn’t go through the terror of the fall. The observer’s hands were clinched as if he had died in agony. His eyes were wide open and staring. The Boches won’t get so fresh around here after this. Its the first one brought down within our lines in this army.

I suppose you are working your pretty titian head off these days — but remember
if you get a chance to write me that you can make me very happy by a note, Marcelle.
